summary.text: Work done equals force times displacement in direction of force: W = Fs cos θ. Work transfers energy between objects. Area under force-distance graph gives work done.

importance.text: Work is energy transfer mechanism. No displacement means no work, regardless of force magnitude. Only force component parallel to motion does work.

explanations.text: Energy must be transferred to change motion. Work quantifies this energy transfer by measuring force applied over distance.
Force alone cannot change energy - there must be displacement. Work is the dot product F·s, capturing only the force component that contributes to motion.
Energy conservation requires precise accounting. Work represents mechanical energy flow between objects through force interactions.
Work = energy flow via force.

questions.text: A constant 25 N force pushes a box 4.0 m horizontally. How much work is done?

options.explanation: This divides force by displacement. Work multiplies them: W = Fs.
This adds force and displacement. Work requires multiplication.
Correct. W = Fs = 25 × 4.0 = 100 J. Force and displacement are parallel.
Check calculation. W = 25 N × 4.0 m = 100 J, not 1000 J.

feedback.correct: Correct. W = Fs when force and displacement are parallel.
feedback.incorrect: Work = force × displacement when parallel.

questions.text: A 40 N force acts at 60° to the direction of motion. The object moves 3.0 m. Work done is:

options.explanation: This uses cos(30°) instead of cos(60°). The angle given is between force and displacement.
This ignores the angle. Only the component parallel to motion does work.
Work is zero only when force is perpendicular (90°). At 60°, some work is done.

feedback.correct: Correct. Only the force component parallel to motion does work.
feedback.incorrect: Use W = Fs cos θ where θ is angle between force and displacement.

questions.text: A car brakes with friction force 800 N over 15 m. Work done by friction is:

options.explanation: Friction opposes motion, so work done by friction is negative.
Correct. Friction opposes motion: W = Fs cos(180°) = 800 × 15 × (-1) = -12000 J.
Friction force has magnitude and displacement occurs, so work is non-zero.
Wrong magnitude and sign. W = 800 × 15 = 12000 J, but negative because friction opposes motion.

feedback.correct: Correct. Friction opposes motion, giving negative work.
feedback.incorrect: Work is negative when force opposes displacement direction.
feedback.explanation: Friction acts opposite to motion: W = 800 × 15 × cos(180°) = -12000 J

questions.text: Which statement about work and energy is correct?

options.text: Work is a form of energy
options.explanation: Work is energy transfer, not energy itself. Energy is a state; work is a process.

options.text: Work equals the change in kinetic energy
options.explanation: This is the work-energy theorem for net work, but individual forces can do work without changing kinetic energy.

options.text: Work is the transfer of energy by mechanical means
options.explanation: Correct. Work represents mechanical energy transfer via force acting through displacement.
Work can be negative when force opposes displacement, representing energy removal.

feedback.correct: Correct. Work is energy transfer mechanism via force.
feedback.incorrect: Work transfers energy mechanically through force acting over displacement.
feedback.explanation: Work is the mechanism by which forces transfer energy between objects.

questions.text: On a force vs distance graph, what does the area under the curve represent?

options.explanation: Power is work per unit time, not area under force-distance graph.
Correct. Area under F-d curve gives work: W = ∫F dx for variable force.
Kinetic energy relates to work via work-energy theorem, but area under F-d curve directly gives work.
Impulse is area under force-time graph, not force-distance graph.

feedback.correct: Correct. Area under F vs d curve gives work done.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: area under force-distance graph = work done.
feedback.explanation: Work = ∫F dx, which is geometrically the area under force vs distance curve.

questions.text: A person carries a 20 kg box horizontally for 50 m at constant velocity. Work done by the person is:

options.explanation: This calculates mgh, but there's no vertical displacement. Weight is perpendicular to motion.
This uses mg for horizontal force, but the person's lifting force is vertical, perpendicular to motion.
Correct. Person applies vertical force to balance weight, but motion is horizontal. Perpendicular force does no work.

options.text: Cannot determine without knowing applied force
options.explanation: The lifting force is vertical (equals weight), motion is horizontal. Perpendicular forces do no work.

feedback.correct: Correct. Perpendicular forces do no work.
feedback.incorrect: Work requires force component parallel to displacement.
feedback.explanation: Person's force is vertical (to balance weight), motion is horizontal. W = Fs cos(90°) = 0.

questions.text: Object moves 10 m under forces: 30 N east, 20 N west, 15 N north. Work done by all forces is:

options.explanation: This adds all force magnitudes. Only net force in direction of motion does work.
Correct. Net force = 30 - 20 = 10 N east. W = 10 × 10 = 100 J. North force is perpendicular.
This uses total horizontal force (30 + 20). Forces in opposite directions subtract.
This includes the north force, but it's perpendicular to eastward motion and does no work.

feedback.correct: Correct. Only net force parallel to motion does work.
feedback.incorrect: Find net force in direction of motion, then calculate work.
feedback.explanation: Net horizontal force = 30 - 20 = 10 N east. W = 10 × 10 = 100 J. North force does no work.

questions.text: The SI unit for work is:

options.explanation: Watt is the unit for power (work per unit time), not work itself.
Correct. Joule = Newton × meter = kg⋅m²⋅s⁻², the SI unit for work and energy.
Newton is the unit for force, not work. Work = force × distance.
Pascal is the unit for pressure (force per unit area), not work.

feedback.correct: Correct. Joule is the SI unit for work and energy.
feedback.incorrect: Work = force × distance, so unit is N⋅m = J.
feedback.explanation: Work has units of force × distance = N⋅m = J (Joule).

questions.text: For variable force, work calculation requires:

options.explanation: This works only if you know the correct average force, but finding average force for variable force requires integration.
Correct. For variable force, work requires integration: W = ∫F⋅dx over the path.
Maximum force doesn't represent work done by variable force throughout motion.
Variable force work can be calculated using integration or by finding area under F-d graph.

feedback.correct: Correct. Variable force requires integration.
feedback.incorrect: For variable force, use W = ∫F dx or area under F-d graph.
feedback.explanation: Variable force work: W = ∫F⋅dx, which is area under force vs distance curve.

questions.text: A machine does 1200 J of useful work using 1500 J of input energy. Its efficiency is:

options.explanation: Efficiency cannot exceed 100%. This inverts the ratio (1500/1200).
Correct. η = useful output/total input = 1200/1500 = 0.80 = 80%.
This calculates waste/input ratio. Efficiency = useful output/total input.
This gives waste energy (1500-1200), not efficiency percentage.

feedback.correct: Correct. Efficiency = useful output/total input.
feedback.incorrect: Efficiency = useful energy out/total energy in.

summary.text: Spring force opposes displacement: F = -kx. Spring constant k measures stiffness. Force is proportional to extension/compression. Negative sign indicates restoring force.

importance.text: Springs store elastic potential energy reversibly. Hooke's law models elastic materials within their elastic limit. Foundation for oscillatory motion and material science.

explanations.text: Materials resist deformation. Elastic forces arise from atomic bonds being stretched or compressed, trying to restore equilibrium length.
Atomic potential energy curves are approximately parabolic near equilibrium. Linear restoring force emerges from quadratic potential energy.
Small displacements probe the harmonic region of interatomic potentials. Hooke's law is the linear approximation to complex many-body interactions.
Springs = linear approximation to atomic forces.

questions.text: A spring with k = 200 N/m is compressed 0.15 m. The spring force is:

options.explanation: Correct. F = kx = 200 × 0.15 = 30 N. Spring force opposes compression, pointing toward equilibrium.
Magnitude is correct, but direction is wrong. Spring force always opposes displacement.
This divides k by x instead of multiplying. F = kx, not k/x.
This divides x by k. Spring force F = kx = 200 × 0.15 = 30 N.

feedback.correct: Correct. F = kx and spring force opposes displacement.
feedback.incorrect: Use F = kx. Spring force always points toward equilibrium position.
feedback.explanation: F = kx = 200 N/m × 0.15 m = 30 N toward equilibrium

questions.text: A force of 80 N stretches a spring 0.20 m. The spring constant is:

options.explanation: This divides force by 5 instead of by displacement. k = F/x = 80/0.20.
Correct. k = F/x = 80 N/0.20 m = 400 N/m.
Check calculation. k = 80/0.20 = 400 N/m, not 100 N/m.
This multiplies F and x instead of dividing. k = F/x, not F × x.

feedback.correct: Correct. Spring constant k = F/x.
feedback.incorrect: Spring constant k = applied force/displacement.

questions.text: Hooke's law F = -kx is valid:

options.explanation: Hooke's law fails for large displacements beyond the elastic limit. Materials can permanently deform or break.
Hooke's law applies to both stretching and compression within the elastic range.
Correct. Hooke's law applies only for small displacements within the material's elastic limit.
Hooke's law applies to any elastic material within its elastic limit, not just metal springs.

feedback.correct: Correct. Hooke's law is valid only within elastic limits.
feedback.incorrect: Hooke's law breaks down for large displacements beyond elastic limit.
feedback.explanation: Beyond elastic limit, materials deform permanently and F ≠ -kx.

questions.text: At equilibrium position, a spring has:

options.explanation: At equilibrium (x = 0), spring force is zero: F = -kx = -k(0) = 0.
Correct. At equilibrium position x = 0, so F = -kx = 0.

options.text: Minimum potential energy and maximum force
options.explanation: Minimum potential energy is correct, but force is zero at equilibrium.
Equilibrium corresponds to minimum potential energy, not maximum.

feedback.correct: Correct. No displacement means no spring force.
feedback.incorrect: At equilibrium position, x = 0, so F = -kx = 0.
feedback.explanation: Equilibrium means x = 0, therefore F = -k(0) = 0 N.

questions.text: A spring stores energy by:

options.explanation: Springs store energy elastically, not as heat. Ideal springs conserve mechanical energy.
Correct. Elastic potential energy comes from reversible deformation of interatomic bonds.
Chemical bonds involve different energy scales. Spring energy is mechanical, not chemical.
This would be thermal energy. Spring potential energy is stored in deformed structure, not molecular motion.

feedback.correct: Correct. Elastic energy comes from deformed bonds.
feedback.incorrect: Springs store energy by reversibly deforming atomic/molecular structure.
feedback.explanation: Stretching/compressing changes bond lengths, storing potential energy reversibly.

questions.text: The negative sign in F = -kx indicates:

options.explanation: Force direction depends on displacement direction. Negative sign indicates opposition, not always negative value.
Spring constant k is always positive. The negative sign is separate from k.
Correct. Negative sign means force direction is opposite to displacement direction - a restoring force.
Displacement can be positive or negative. The negative sign ensures force opposes whatever displacement occurs.

feedback.correct: Correct. Spring force is a restoring force.
feedback.incorrect: Negative sign means force opposes displacement direction.
feedback.explanation: If x > 0 (stretched), F < 0 (pulls back). If x < 0 (compressed), F > 0 (pushes back).

questions.text: Two springs with k₁ = 100 N/m and k₂ = 200 N/m connected in parallel have effective spring constant:

options.explanation: This uses series formula (reciprocals). For parallel springs, spring constants add directly.
This averages the spring constants. For parallel, they add: k_eff = k₁ + k₂.
Correct. In parallel, both springs stretch equally, so forces add: k_eff = k₁ + k₂ = 100 + 200 = 300 N/m.
This multiplies the spring constants. For parallel: k_eff = k₁ + k₂, not k₁ × k₂.

feedback.correct: Correct. Parallel springs add their spring constants.
feedback.incorrect: In parallel, both springs experience same displacement, forces add.
feedback.explanation: Parallel: same displacement, forces add. k_eff = k₁ + k₂ = 300 N/m.

questions.text: Work done stretching a spring (k = 500 N/m) from 0.10 m to 0.30 m is:

options.explanation: This uses average force × distance. For springs, use W = ½k(x₂² - x₁²).
This calculates ½kx₂² only. Must subtract initial elastic potential energy: ½k(x₂² - x₁²).
This uses kx₂ instead of ½k(x₂² - x₁²). Work on spring requires integration due to variable force.

feedback.correct: Correct. Work = change in elastic potential energy.
feedback.incorrect: For variable spring force, W = ½k(x_final² - x_initial²).

questions.text: A stiffer spring has:

options.explanation: Stiffer springs resist deformation more, requiring larger force for same displacement. This means higher k.
Correct. Stiffer spring needs more force for same displacement: F = kx, so larger F for same x means larger k.
Stiffness relates to force-displacement ratio, not natural length of spring.
Maximum extension depends on elastic limit, not stiffness. Stiffer springs often have smaller elastic limits.

feedback.correct: Correct. Stiffness means larger force needed for given displacement.
feedback.incorrect: Stiffer spring = harder to deform = higher spring constant k.
feedback.explanation: k = F/x. Stiffer spring needs more force F for same displacement x.

questions.text: When a mass oscillates on a spring, the restoring force is maximum when:

options.explanation: Maximum velocity occurs at equilibrium where displacement and force are zero.
Correct. F = -kx, so maximum |F| occurs when |x| is maximum (at turning points).
Zero acceleration means zero net force. Restoring force is maximum when acceleration is maximum.
Maximum kinetic energy occurs at equilibrium where restoring force is zero.

feedback.correct: Correct. Maximum displacement gives maximum restoring force.
feedback.incorrect: F = -kx, so |F| is maximum when |x| is maximum.
feedback.explanation: At maximum displacement (turning points), velocity = 0 but restoring force = maximum.

summary.text: Mechanical energy = kinetic + potential energy. KE = ½mv², GPE = mgh, EPE = ½kx². Energy conserved when only conservative forces act. Work by non-conservative forces changes total mechanical energy.

importance.text: Energy conservation is fundamental physics principle. Allows solving complex motion problems without detailed force analysis. Links microscopic and macroscopic descriptions of matter.

explanations.text: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed. Mechanical energy tracks kinetic and potential contributions to total energy.
Noether's theorem: energy conservation follows from time translation symmetry. Physical laws don't change with time shift.
Spacetime geometry determines energy-momentum conservation. Energy conservation emerges from the structure of space and time itself.
Energy conservation = time symmetry.

questions.text: A 5.0 kg object moves at 8.0 m/s. Its kinetic energy is:

options.explanation: This uses KE = mv instead of KE = ½mv². Missing the factor of ½.
This uses KE = mv instead of ½mv². The ½ factor is essential.
This uses KE = mv² without the ½ factor. Kinetic energy is ½mv², not mv².

feedback.correct: Correct. KE = ½mv² with the essential ½ factor.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: KE = ½mv², don't forget the ½.

questions.text: A 2.0 kg book is lifted 1.5 m above the ground. Its gravitational potential energy increases by:

options.explanation: This omits gravitational field strength. ΔPE = mgΔh = mg(1.5).
Check calculation. ΔPE = mgΔh = 2.0 × 9.8 × 1.5.
Correct. ΔPE = mgΔh = 2.0 × 9.8 × 1.5 = 29.4 J.
This uses wrong height or calculation. ΔPE = 2.0 × 9.8 × 1.5 = 29.4 J.

feedback.correct: Correct. ΔPE = mgΔh for gravitational potential energy.
feedback.incorrect: Use ΔPE = mgΔh where g = 9.8 m/s².
feedback.explanation: ΔPE = mgΔh = 2.0 kg × 9.8 m/s² × 1.5 m = 29.4 J

questions.text: A spring (k = 400 N/m) compressed 0.20 m stores elastic potential energy of:

options.explanation: This uses EPE = kx instead of ½kx². The ½ factor is essential for elastic potential energy.
This appears to use wrong calculation. EPE = ½kx² = ½(400)(0.04) = 8.0 J. Wait, let me recalculate...
Check calculation: EPE = ½(400)(0.20)² = ½(400)(0.04) = 8.0 J.

feedback.correct: Correct. EPE = ½kx² for springs.
feedback.incorrect: Use EPE = ½kx² for elastic potential energy.

questions.text: A pendulum swings from rest at height h. Its speed at the bottom is:

options.explanation: Missing factor of 2. At bottom: mgh = ½mv², so v² = 2gh, giving v = √(2gh).
Correct. Energy conservation: mgh = ½mv², so v² = 2gh, therefore v = √(2gh).
This puts the 2 outside the square root incorrectly. From v² = 2gh, we get v = √(2gh).
This doesn't take square root. From ½mv² = mgh, we get v² = 2gh, so v = √(2gh).

feedback.correct: Correct. Energy conservation gives v = √(2gh).
feedback.incorrect: Use energy conservation: PE at top = KE at bottom.
feedback.explanation: mgh = ½mv² → v² = 2gh → v = √(2gh)

questions.text: The work-energy theorem states:

options.explanation: This is the definition of work, not the work-energy theorem.

options.text: Net work equals change in kinetic energy
options.explanation: Correct. W_net = ΔKE is the work-energy theorem.

options.text: Work equals change in potential energy
options.explanation: Work by conservative forces equals negative change in potential energy, but work-energy theorem relates to kinetic energy.
Work can change mechanical energy, but work-energy theorem specifically relates net work to kinetic energy change.

feedback.correct: Correct. Net work done equals change in kinetic energy.
feedback.incorrect: Work-energy theorem: W_net = ΔKE.
feedback.explanation: W_net = KE_final - KE_initial = ΔKE

questions.text: Which force is non-conservative?

options.explanation: Gravity is conservative. Work done depends only on initial and final heights, not path taken.
Spring force is conservative. Work done depends only on initial and final compressions/extensions.
Correct. Friction is non-conservative. Work done by friction depends on path length and always removes mechanical energy.
Electric force is conservative. Work done depends only on initial and final positions.

feedback.correct: Correct. Friction depends on path and dissipates energy.
feedback.incorrect: Conservative forces: work independent of path. Non-conservative: work depends on path.
feedback.explanation: Friction work depends on distance traveled and always removes mechanical energy.

questions.text: A ball thrown upward has maximum potential energy when:

options.explanation: At release, ball has maximum kinetic energy but minimum potential energy (lowest height).
Correct. At maximum height, velocity = 0 (minimum KE) and height is maximum (maximum PE).
At return to original height, potential energy equals initial value, not maximum.

options.text: Potential energy is constant throughout flight
options.explanation: Potential energy changes with height: PE = mgh.

feedback.correct: Correct. Maximum height gives maximum potential energy.
feedback.incorrect: PE = mgh is maximum when h is maximum.
feedback.explanation: At top of trajectory: v = 0, h = maximum, so PE = mgh = maximum.

questions.text: All forms of energy are measured in:

options.explanation: Watts measure power (energy per unit time), not energy itself.
Correct. Joule is the SI unit for all forms of energy: kinetic, potential, heat, etc.
Newtons measure force, not energy. Energy = force × distance.
Kilograms measure mass. Energy involves mass but has different units.

feedback.correct: Correct. Joule is the universal energy unit.
feedback.incorrect: All energy forms use joules: kinetic, potential, thermal, etc.
feedback.explanation: 1 J = 1 kg⋅m²⋅s⁻² = 1 N⋅m for all energy types.

questions.text: When mechanical energy is 'lost' to friction, it becomes:

options.explanation: Energy cannot be destroyed. It transforms into other forms, particularly thermal energy.
Correct. Friction converts organized mechanical energy into random molecular motion (heat).
Friction typically converts mechanical energy to heat, not recoverable potential energy.
Mass-energy conversion requires nuclear processes. Friction involves much smaller energy scales.

feedback.correct: Correct. Friction converts mechanical energy to heat.
feedback.incorrect: Friction transforms ordered motion into random molecular motion (heat).
feedback.explanation: Sliding friction increases temperature by converting mechanical energy to thermal energy.

questions.text: A machine has 60% efficiency. If 500 J of work is input, the useful output work is:

options.explanation: This calculates waste energy (40% of 500 J). Useful output = efficiency × input.
Correct. Useful output = efficiency × input = 0.60 × 500 J = 300 J.
This inverts the calculation (500/0.6). Efficiency = output/input, so output = efficiency × input.
This ignores efficiency losses. With 60% efficiency, only 60% of input becomes useful output.

feedback.correct: Correct. Useful output = efficiency × input.
feedback.incorrect: Efficiency = useful output/total input.
feedback.explanation: Useful output = 0.60 × 500 J = 300 J. Waste = 200 J.

summary.text: Power measures energy transfer rate: P = E/t. Also P = Fv for moving objects. Power determines how quickly work gets done or energy gets transferred between systems.

importance.text: Power distinguishes between energy and energy transfer rate. Critical for engineering design - machines need adequate power for required tasks. Links force, velocity, and energy concepts.

explanations.text: Time matters for practical applications. Same energy transferred slowly vs quickly has different consequences and requirements.
Power represents energy flux - how much energy flows per unit time. Like current in electricity or mass flow in fluids.
Power emerges from energy conservation in time-dependent systems. Rate of energy change equals power input minus output.
Power = energy flow rate.

questions.text: A machine transfers 1200 J of energy in 4.0 s. Its power output is:

options.explanation: Correct. P = E/t = 1200 J / 4.0 s = 300 W.
This multiplies energy and time. Power equals energy divided by time.
This adds energy and time. Power = energy/time, not energy + time.
This subtracts time from energy. Use P = E/t = 1200/4.0.

feedback.correct: Correct. Power = energy transferred per unit time.
feedback.incorrect: Power P = energy E divided by time t.

questions.text: A 500 N force moves an object at constant 6.0 m/s. The power delivered is:

options.explanation: This divides force by velocity. Power = force × velocity when parallel.
This adds force and velocity. Power = force × velocity, not force + velocity.
Correct. P = Fv = 500 N × 6.0 m/s = 3000 W when force and velocity are parallel.
Check calculation. P = Fv = 500 × 6.0 = 3000 W, not 18000 W.

feedback.correct: Correct. P = Fv when force and velocity are parallel.
feedback.incorrect: For constant velocity, P = Fv where F is applied force.

questions.text: The SI unit for power is:

options.explanation: Joule is the unit for energy. Power = energy/time has units J/s = W.
Correct. Watt = J/s = kg⋅m²⋅s⁻³ is the SI unit for power.
Newton is the unit for force. Power involves energy and time.
This has wrong dimensions. Power = energy/time = J/s = W.

feedback.correct: Correct. Watt is the SI power unit.
feedback.incorrect: Power = energy/time, so unit is J/s = W (Watt).
feedback.explanation: 1 W = 1 J/s = 1 kg⋅m²⋅s⁻³

questions.text: Two motors do the same work. Motor A takes 2.0 s, Motor B takes 8.0 s. Motor A's power is:

options.explanation: Motor A is faster (less time), so it has higher power. P = W/t.
Same work but different times means different power. P = W/t.
Ratio is 8.0/2.0 = 4.0, not 6. Motor A has 4 times the power.

feedback.correct: Correct. Less time for same work means more power.
feedback.incorrect: Power = work/time. Same work, less time = more power.
feedback.explanation: P_A = W/2.0, P_B = W/8.0, so P_A = 4P_B

questions.text: A motor with 85% efficiency draws 2000 W electrical power. Its mechanical power output is:

options.explanation: Correct. Mechanical output = efficiency × electrical input = 0.85 × 2000 W = 1700 W.
This ignores efficiency losses. Only 85% of input power becomes useful mechanical output.
This inverts the calculation (2000/0.85). Output = efficiency × input, not input/efficiency.
This calculates waste power (15% of 2000 W). Useful output = 85% of input.

feedback.correct: Correct. Output power = efficiency × input power.
feedback.incorrect: Efficiency = output power/input power.
feedback.explanation: Mechanical output = 0.85 × 2000 W = 1700 W

questions.text: If power remains constant, doubling velocity requires the applied force to:

options.explanation: From P = Fv, if P constant and v doubles, then F must halve to maintain P = Fv.
Correct. P = Fv, so F = P/v. If v doubles, F must halve to keep P constant.
This would make power increase by factor of 8 (2 × 4), not remain constant.
If F stays same and v doubles, power would double (P = Fv), not remain constant.

feedback.correct: Correct. P = Fv, so F ∝ 1/v when P is constant.
feedback.incorrect: From P = Fv, if P constant then F ∝ 1/v.
feedback.explanation: P = Fv constant means F = P/v. Double v → halve F.

questions.text: A 1500 W heater runs for 20 minutes. Energy consumed is:

options.explanation: This divides power by time. Energy = power × time.
This uses 20 minutes without converting to seconds. E = Pt = 1500 × 1200 s.
This adds power and time. Energy = power × time, not power + time.

feedback.correct: Correct. Energy = power × time.
feedback.incorrect: Convert time to seconds: 20 min = 1200 s, then E = Pt.

questions.text: A 70 kg person climbs 15 m high stairs in 25 s. Average power output against gravity is:

options.explanation: Check calculation. Work against gravity = mgh = 70 × 9.8 × 15, then P = W/t.
This uses t = 10 s instead of 25 s. P = 10290 J / 25 s = 411 W.
Check gravitational PE calculation: mgh = 70 × 9.8 × 15 = 10290 J.

feedback.correct: Correct. Power = work done against gravity / time.
feedback.incorrect: Work against gravity = mgh, then P = W/t.

questions.text: A car maintains 30 m/s against 800 N air resistance. Engine power needed is:

options.explanation: This divides force by velocity. Power = force × velocity when parallel.
Correct. P = Fv = 800 N × 30 m/s = 24000 W = 24 kW.
This adds force and velocity. Power = force × velocity, not force + velocity.
Check calculation: P = Fv = 800 × 30 = 24000 W.

feedback.correct: Correct. Power needed = drag force × velocity.
feedback.incorrect: At constant velocity, engine force = drag force. P = Fv.

questions.text: If power doubles and time halves, the energy transferred:

options.explanation: Correct. E = Pt. If P doubles and t halves: E = (2P)(t/2) = Pt = same.
E = Pt. When P doubles and t halves, they cancel: E unchanged.
E = Pt. Doubling P and halving t gives E = 2P × t/2 = Pt.
This would occur if both P and t doubled. Here P doubles but t halves.

feedback.correct: Correct. Doubling power but halving time gives same energy.
feedback.incorrect: E = Pt. Changes in P and t can cancel each other.
feedback.explanation: E = Pt. New: E = (2P)(t/2) = Pt = original energy.

summary.text: Impulse equals change in momentum: FΔt = Δp = mΔv. Momentum conserved in isolated systems. Total momentum before collision equals total momentum after collision.

importance.text: Momentum conservation is universal - applies to all interactions. Impulse explains why force and time both matter for changing motion. Essential for collision analysis and rocket propulsion.

explanations.text: Newton's third law ensures momentum conservation. When objects interact, forces are equal and opposite, so momentum transfers between them.
Momentum conservation follows from spatial translation symmetry via Noether's theorem. Space has no preferred location.
Momentum emerges from gauge symmetries in field theory. Conservation laws reflect fundamental symmetries of spacetime.
Momentum conservation = space symmetry.

questions.text: A 40 N force acts for 3.0 s. The impulse delivered is:

options.explanation: This divides force by time. Impulse = force × time.
Correct. Impulse = FΔt = 40 N × 3.0 s = 120 N⋅s.
This adds force and time. Impulse = force × time, not force + time.
This subtracts time from force. Impulse = FΔt = 40 × 3.0.

feedback.correct: Correct. Impulse = force × time interval.
feedback.incorrect: Impulse = FΔt when force is constant.
feedback.explanation: Impulse = FΔt = 40 N × 3.0 s = 120 N⋅s

questions.text: Two objects collide and stick together. This collision is:

options.explanation: Elastic collisions conserve kinetic energy. Objects sticking together lose kinetic energy.
Correct. Objects sticking together defines a perfectly inelastic collision.
Momentum is conserved in all collisions. Kinetic energy is not conserved in inelastic collisions.

options.text: Only possible if masses are equal
options.explanation: Objects can stick together regardless of their masses. Momentum is always conserved.

feedback.correct: Correct. Sticking together = perfectly inelastic collision.
feedback.incorrect: Objects sticking defines perfectly inelastic collision.
feedback.explanation: Perfectly inelastic: objects stick together after collision.

questions.text: A 1500 kg car travels at 25 m/s. Its momentum is:

options.explanation: This divides mass by velocity. Momentum = mass × velocity.
This adds mass and velocity. Momentum = mass × velocity, not mass + velocity.
Correct. p = mv = 1500 kg × 25 m/s = 37500 kg⋅m/s.
Right magnitude, wrong units. Momentum units are kg⋅m/s, not N.

feedback.correct: Correct. Momentum = mass × velocity.
feedback.incorrect: p = mv with units kg⋅m/s.

questions.text: A 2.0 kg object at 8.0 m/s collides with a 3.0 kg object at rest. After collision, the 2.0 kg object moves at 2.0 m/s. The 3.0 kg object's velocity is:

options.explanation: Correct. Momentum conservation: 2.0×8.0 = 2.0×2.0 + 3.0×v₂. So 16 = 4 + 3v₂, giving v₂ = 4.0 m/s.
Check momentum conservation: initial = 16 kg⋅m/s, final must equal this.
This assumes equal final velocities, but momentum conservation gives different result.
This would violate momentum conservation. Apply p_initial = p_final.

feedback.correct: Correct. Apply momentum conservation: p_before = p_after.
feedback.incorrect: Use momentum conservation: m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = m₁v₁ + m₂v₂.

questions.text: Impulse equals:

options.explanation: Force times distance equals work, not impulse.
Correct. Impulse = Δp = change in momentum = FΔt.
Change in kinetic energy equals work done, not impulse.
Mass times acceleration equals force, not impulse.

feedback.correct: Correct. Impulse-momentum theorem: impulse = Δp.
feedback.incorrect: Impulse = FΔt = Δp = change in momentum.
feedback.explanation: Impulse-momentum theorem: FΔt = Δp

questions.text: Momentum is a vector because:

options.explanation: Magnitude doesn't determine vector nature. Direction is the key property.
Correct. p = mv, and since velocity is a vector, momentum is also a vector.
Mass is a scalar quantity. Momentum gets its vector nature from velocity.
Units don't determine vector nature. Vector property comes from directional components.

feedback.correct: Correct. Momentum inherits vector nature from velocity.
feedback.incorrect: p = mv. Mass is scalar, velocity is vector, so momentum is vector.
feedback.explanation: Since velocity has direction, momentum p = mv also has direction.

questions.text: An object at rest explodes into two pieces with equal mass. The pieces move:

options.text: In the same direction with equal speeds
options.explanation: This would not conserve momentum. Initial momentum was zero.

options.text: In opposite directions with equal speeds
options.explanation: Correct. Equal masses moving at equal speeds in opposite directions gives zero total momentum.

options.text: In opposite directions with different speeds
options.explanation: Equal masses must have equal speeds to conserve momentum (initial momentum = 0).
Momentum conservation constrains the motion. Equal masses must move in opposite directions with equal speeds.

feedback.correct: Correct. Equal masses need equal opposite velocities for zero momentum.
feedback.incorrect: Initial momentum = 0, so final momentum must = 0.
feedback.explanation: m₁v₁ + m₂v₂ = 0. If m₁ = m₂, then v₁ = -v₂.

questions.text: Same impulse can be delivered by:

options.text: Large force for short time or small force for long time
options.explanation: Correct. Impulse = FΔt, so F and Δt are inversely related for constant impulse.
Small forces acting for long times can deliver same impulse as large forces for short times.
Long time intervals with appropriate force can deliver any required impulse.
Force times time equals momentum change. Force alone doesn't determine impulse.

feedback.correct: Correct. Impulse = FΔt allows force-time trade-offs.
feedback.incorrect: Same impulse: large F × small Δt = small F × large Δt.
feedback.explanation: Impulse = FΔt. To get same impulse, F and Δt are inversely related.

questions.text: Momentum is conserved in:

options.explanation: Momentum conserved only if net external force is zero (isolated system).
Correct. Momentum conservation requires no net external forces acting on the system.
Momentum conserved in both elastic and inelastic collisions if system is isolated.
Friction is external force that can change system momentum.

feedback.correct: Correct. No external forces means momentum is conserved.
feedback.incorrect: Momentum conservation requires isolated system (no net external forces).
feedback.explanation: If F_external = 0, then Δp_total = 0 (momentum conserved).

questions.text: Airbags reduce injury by:

options.explanation: Momentum change is determined by initial and final velocities, not by airbag.
Correct. Same Δp over longer Δt means smaller average force: F = Δp/Δt.
Impulse equals momentum change, which is determined by velocity change, not airbag.
Forces are needed to change momentum. Airbags reduce average force magnitude, not eliminate forces.

feedback.correct: Correct. Longer collision time reduces average force.
feedback.incorrect: F = Δp/Δt. Same Δp, longer Δt means smaller F.
feedback.explanation: Airbags extend collision time, reducing F_average = Δp/Δt.
